content.title: Strategic Energy Planning At The Policy Level
content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

Strategic energy planning plays a critical role in addressing key challenges faced by developing nations, such as energy security, economic competitiveness, and climate change mitigation. Effective long-term planning requires a holistic approach that integrates resource assessment, infrastructure development, and stakeholder engagement. Aligning policy goals with planning, monitoring, and evaluation (PM&E) frameworks ensures that energy projects are both sustainable and responsive to diverse stakeholder needs.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: adaptive planning
concepts.body: Adaptive planning is a flexible approach to planning that allows for adjustments and changes in response to new information, uncertainties, and evolving conditions, particularly in the context of environmental and sustainability challenges.

concepts.title: energy system modeling
concepts.body: Energy system modeling is the process of creating mathematical representations of energy systems to analyze and predict their behavior, performance, and interactions under various scenarios.

concepts.title: long-term energy objectives
concepts.body: Long-term energy objectives are strategic goals set by governments, organizations, or communities aimed at achieving sustainable energy use, reducing carbon emissions, and transitioning to renewable energy sources over an extended period, typically spanning decades.

content.text: The need to strengthen energy planning capabilities in developing countries has become increasingly evident in recent years. Revitalizing strategic energy planning agencies and adopting advanced planning models are often necessary to address evolving energy paradigms. These paradigms reflect the effects of climate change, shifts in global politics and financial systems, energy price volatility, and changing public expectations about the responsibilities of the energy sector. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) emphasizes that energy planning models aim to ensure decisions regarding energy demand and supply infrastructures are inclusive, comprehensive, and aligned with national sustainable development goals (IAEA, 2022). Similarly, long-term energy planning helps shape informed policy discussions by exploring socio-technical pathways in the energy sector, enabling governments to craft coherent, forward-looking policies (Akpahou et al., 2024).

Long-term energy planning involves defining national or regional targets, policies, and investment strategies based on quantitative analyses of energy scenarios, often supported by energy system modeling. This process is central to global energy policy-making, guiding decisions on when, where, and how to invest in energy infrastructure (IRENA, 2024). Effective energy planning extends beyond the energy sector itself, intersecting with domestic and international policies and addressing critical areas such as natural resources, industry, trade, and the environment. It provides a strategic framework for achieving clear goals, engaging stakeholders across government, the private sector, civil society, and citizens. While many nations have established strong practices in this domain, the ongoing energy transition requires a fresh evaluation of planning methodologies to meet new and evolving challenges.

To support clean energy transitions, long-term energy plans must align with other critical areas, including climate change and water management. With energy-related activities contributing approximately 75% of global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, these areas are deeply interconnected. For example, regions relying on hydropower should carefully consider the water-energy nexus from a regional perspective.

Energy policy planners have made strides in integrating critical minerals into clean energy strategies, but their focus must also encompass common materials essential for the transition. Moreover, energy policies should address broader social and economic impacts, such as creating green jobs and improving energy access. Without a strategic, holistic approach, governments risk developing fragmented policies that fail to address energy and climate challenges comprehensively. Effective long-term planning should encompass the entire energy system rather than isolate its individual components. This integrated approach enables policymakers to identify and prioritize system-wide solutions, which are often overlooked when focusing on specific technologies, commodities, or sectors in isolation.

content.title: Part 1: A Systemic approach

content.text: Part 1 Overview

The relationship between energy and society is multifaceted, influencing politics, economics, and daily life. As energy systems grow increasingly complex—spanning technical, social, geopolitical, economic, and environmental dimensions—the need for government intervention becomes paramount. Historically, energy planning narrowly focused on ensuring supply met demand, but crises like the 1973 oil shock underscored the importance of a more integrated approach. Today, energy systems are seen as encompassing not only production and distribution but also their broader social and environmental impacts, with policies emphasizing efficiency, resource substitution, and the role of consumption patterns.

Energy systems are unique in functioning as both strategic goods and public services, demanding a systemic approach to management. Public policy intervention, anchored in robust energy planning, is critical for aligning energy goals with sustainable development objectives. This multidisciplinary approach integrates energy's interconnected roles within society, the economy, and the environment. Ultimately, the State plays an irreplaceable role in crafting and implementing active energy policies. Leaving resource allocation to public or private stakeholders risks sidelining societal priorities. Effective energy planning ensures systems meet collective needs, advancing sustainable and equitable development (OLADE, 2016).

content.title: Case Study: Implementing a Long-Term Energy Policy Planning Process for Azerbaijan

content.text: Case Study RBeC: Implementing a Long-Term Energy Policy Planning Process for Azerbaijan

The project "Implementing a Long-Term Energy Policy Planning Process for Azerbaijan: A Roadmap" aims to establish a strategic direction for Azerbaijan's energy sector, ensuring energy security, access, and trade while contributing to a net-zero future. Financially supported by EU4Energy—a collaboration between the IEA, the European Union, focus countries, and other implementing parties—this initiative seeks to develop a comprehensive long-term energy strategy for Azerbaijan.

Azerbaijan's roadmap integrates key laws and reforms into a comprehensive energy strategy, emphasizing sustainability and collaboration between policymakers and statisticians for in-house modelling capability. A long-term plan can significantly facilitate the country’s energy path, necessitating government action to drive meaningful change. Azerbaijan's focus on energy efficiency aims to reduce its heavy reliance on oil and gas. The assessment concludes that Azerbaijan should prioritize comprehensive energy statistics covering its entire energy supply and usage, ensuring these data are accessible through increased cooperation among government ministries. By expanding energy statistics, particularly on the demand side, Azerbaijan can use energy modelling to effectively achieve its long-term goals. Azerbaijan's timeline for developing a long-term energy strategy is uncertain due to limited demand-side data. However, strategic planning and goal-setting could begin simultaneously with the statistical survey process. To ensure accurate policy planning and energy modelling, it is crucial to collect quality energy statistics, including data on end uses of energy. The assessment advises using results from the 2018 household energy consumption survey to set targets for the residential sector. However, instead of relying on a single survey, a series of surveys conducted every two to three years is recommended to properly monitor changes in energy use. It is also advised to build different 2050 scenarios using an Energy Modelling Tool, with complexity varying depending on data availability. Given that this is one of the most pressing issues, a series of strategies are suggested to develop a minimum viable model that can be adapted to suit specific needs and answer complex questions.

Developing an energy strategy with a long-term perspective is crucial given global commitments like the Paris Agreement. Energy security, access, and trade play key roles in achieving a net-zero future. Informed policy planning, tailored to each country's priorities, ensures success. The connection between energy policy planning and creating an energy strategy sets goals and enables effective handling of challenges. Comprehensive energy statistics and political thought leadership support long-term planning and strategy evolution. By setting a clear roadmap and focusing on strategic, data-driven planning, Azerbaijan can navigate its energy transition, ensuring sustainability and resilience in its energy sector.

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Energy planning as a management tool for sustainable development

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Energy planning is a continuous and dynamic process, not a one-time event. Its value lies not just in creating an energy plan but in ensuring its effective execution, monitoring, and adaptation to evolving circumstances. Given the inherent uncertainty in energy systems, periodic revisions are essential to incorporate new information and address changing variables, such as economic shifts, technological advances, or political developments. A robust energy plan provides guidance during uncertain times, identifying flexible and resilient strategies that reduce risk while preparing for future challenges. Effective planning aligns the operation of energy systems with long-term goals, emphasizing flexibility and adaptability within a structured framework.

A comprehensive energy plan integrates diverse objectives, such as ensuring energy supply security, fostering market development, minimizing environmental impacts, promoting energy efficiency, and advancing social goals like poverty alleviation and sustainable economic growth. Achieving these goals requires contributions from all relevant stakeholders and a clear definition of roles and responsibilities within the energy sector. The planning process involves setting long-term objectives, selecting appropriate methodologies, analyzing inputs, and periodically updating the plan to reflect current conditions. This approach enables countries to address sustainability priorities while developing viable strategies supported by legal and regulatory frameworks. Ultimately, energy planning serves as a roadmap for creating coherent and actionable strategies that integrate energy systems into broader national objectives for economic development and social progress (OLADE, 2016).

content.intro: M7: Data In Sustainable Energy | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Open-Source Energy Modeling System (OSeMOSYS)

content.text: Case Study RBAS: Open-Source Energy Modeling System (OSeMOSYS)

Energy is a key component of economic and social development, and it needs careful planning so that it reflects the three pillars of sustainability (social, economic, and environmental). For sustainable energy development to be achieved, energy modeling is indispensable for data-driven decision-making. There are a number of energy modeling tools in use today, each serving its own particular purpose. The choice of a modeling tool to use depends on the needs and characteristics of the region or country under study.

Morocco is one of the countries under the Regional Bureau for Arab States (RBAS) with an energy system dominated by fossil fuels, with approximately 80% conventional power generation as of 2019.1 These fossil fuel-fired power plants contribute the most greenhouse gas emissions. To reduce such emissions and align with Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), the country has the opportunity to explore either of the following pathways: to introduce a carbon tax as a policy instrument to discourage the use of fossil fuels in power generation systems or to impose emission limits on power generation. To assess the viability and impacts of the proposed options, the Open-Source Energy Modeling System (OSeMOSYS) was used. OSeMOSYS is a freely available energy modeling tool developed to help developing nations model their energy systems. It is a techno-economic optimization model that uses a bottom-up modeling approach. The objective function of the tool is to minimize the net present cost of the modeled energy systems, taking into consideration user-specified constraints while meeting the exogenously defined energy demand.2 Thus, under the Moroccan case (Comparative effectiveness of environmental regulation instruments: Case of the Moroccan electricity mix), the constraints were the imposed carbon tax in the first scenario and the emission target for the second scenario. In the modeling process, an interest rate of 5% was assumed, and the capital cost of conventional power generators would remain constant while that of renewable energy technologies would continue to decrease. However, in most developing countries, such an interest rate would not be realistic, and technology costs are not certain.

The results revealed that carbon taxes are more effective in reducing carbon emissions as compared to emission targets. These results show that the carbon tax directly affects the production costs of conventional energy technologies and makes renewable energy technologies (RET) more economically suitable. However, this depends on the cost or value of the carbon tax and the intended carbon emission target. The lower the carbon tax, the lesser the effect it has on the production cost of fossil fuel-fired power plants. Both scenarios favor the installation of RETs, particularly solar and wind.

The study gave an insight into how different policy instruments can be used to achieve a particular target. However, it is imperative to assess how each will have an impact on the generation and consumption of energy. Furthermore, the study can serve as a policy recommendation on the appropriate policy instrument to implement, as in this case, a carbon tax emerged as a better option to curb carbon emissions. In addition, policies that enhance the manufacture or supply of RETs can be implemented to augment the RETs needed to meet the set emission reduction targets. In conclusion, a study of this nature can be easily replicated in any jurisdiction as long as the needed data for modeling is available, and it has highlighted that energy modeling is indeed crucial in the selection of policy instruments for sustainable energy development.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Strategic energy planning is essential for addressing energy security, economic competitiveness, and climate change.
takeaways.description: Integrating resource assessment, infrastructure, and stakeholder engagement helps governments align policies with sustainable development and navigate energy transitions effectively.

takeaways.title: Energy planning must adapt to evolving challenges.
takeaways.description: Continuous updates to energy plans ensure flexibility and resilience, allowing countries to respond to economic, technological, and political changes while meeting long-term objectives.

takeaways.title: Energy modeling tools drive sustainable energy decisions.
takeaways.description: Tools like OSeMOSYS enable scenario simulation and policy impact assessment, helping policymakers optimize energy systems and balance economic and environmental goals.
